Journal Story:
Sometime around fifteen years ago I read an article about the Appalachian trail.The piece mentioned that some hikers would complete the entire 2175 mile trail from Georgia to Maine over the course of a single summer. I began reading everything I could find on thru hiking. I started doing some four and five day backpacking trips on the Superior hiking trail in Minnesota with the idea of one day thru hiking the Appalachian trail. 
So fast forward fifteen years and the time seems right to finally attempt to get this done. I will try to update this journal daily from the trail with a photo and a paragraph or two of highlights from each day.

For those that are interested in the gear that I will be carrying,there is a link labeled gear on the left side of the page.
My pack weight to start the hike with three days of food and one liter of water is 19.5 pounds

Only four days till Stacy and I leave for Atlanta. There we will rent a car and drive to Dahlonega GA to spend the night. Tuesday morning Stacy and I will drive to a parking area on Forest Service road 42. From there we will walk a mile south to the official start of the trail . After pictures we will walk the official first mile together before parting ways at the car.
I am sure that goodbye will be the hardest thing I have to do on the trail. Words can’t express how fortunate I feel to have a wife that supports me in this selfish endeavor after everything she has been through. She is truly the strongest person I know.
We made it to Georgia. Spending the night at Barefoot Hills Hostel in Dahlonega. Cool place. Early tomorrow Stacy drives me to the trail.

Change of plans. We decided against driving up the long dirt road to a parking area near the beginning of the trail. Opted instead to do the eight mile approach trail that takes you to the top of Springer Mountain. Tough trail. Completed that along with first eight miles of the official AT. Sixteen miles total for the day. It’s great to finally be out here.

Rainy night last night. Packed up quickly and hit the trail at 8:00. Great group at the shelter last night. There must have been 50 tents. Three people were from  Illinois and a guy from South Africa that has never seen snow. Predicting snow up here for Saturday.Had a hard time finding a camping location and ended up hiking 23 miles. That is more miles than I would like to do this early in the hike but I feel good. Crazy winds tonight gusts up to 30 miles per hour.

Easier 11.5 mile day today. I resupplied at Mountain Outfitters at Neels Gap this morning and left around 9:00 The trail passes directly through the store. Many hikers quit here. The tree out front is filled with shoes from hikers that had enough. Two days from the Top of Georgia Hostel where a shower and laundry await.
Today’s miles seemed easier. Only eleven miles to Top of Georgia hostel tomorrow but rain all day and a chance of snow will make them interesting.
Good night at the hostel after an easier 11 mile walk. Went to town with a large group for Mexican good. Back at it tomorrow for a longer day

One State Done.Excited to exit Georgia and enter North Carolina today. Walked through a crazy ice storm. Probably a half inch of ice on the trail in spots. I took a video that I will try to post when I get to town.

It rained all night. I woke up and packed up quickly as it was in the low 30’s. Today’s hike was the easiest so far. Nice and soft, less elevation gain and fewer rocks and roots. That is until I reached Albert Mountain, elevation 5020. The climb required using my hands at times. There was a fire tower but no views because of the dense fog. No pictures today to rainy and foggy.
I had an awesome walk today. The skies were clear for the first time since day one. Today’s highlight was a climb of Wayah Bald elevation 5337.  Eighteen miles for the day. Shorter day tomorrow.

Easy ten mile day today. Sunny and 55 degrees. Perfect weather for hiking.Highlight was an observation tower on top of Wessex Bald.Tomorrow a quick six miles to the Nantahala Outdoor Center where I will spend the night at the hostel and resupply. I may take a day off before entering the Smokies next week. Bad weather predicted for Sunday and Monday.

Took it easy today.  Six down hill miles to the Nantahala  Outdoor Center.  Great place where you can book kayak and rafting tours. I spent the day there washing clothes, showering, eating and drinking beer. Good day, but tomorrow will be sixteen miles uphill from the gap.
It felt good to get back on the trail today.  Today was one of the toughest days so far.  The climbs were longer and steeper.  Rocks covered a large portion of today’s trail.

I made to it Fontana Village which is the gateway to Smoky Mountains National Park.  Terrible weather forecasted for the next couple of days in the Smokies, so I am going to take a zero day on Sunday (No miles hiked.)
Spending the day organizing food and gear.  It's harder to take a day off than I thought it would be.  The weather is miserable though so happy to be indoors.

Headed into the Smoky Mountain National Park today. As soon as I dropped my permit into the box while entering the park it began to snow.  The snow along with high winds made for a difficult hike.  Nighttime brought a low of 18 and 35 mile an hour winds.  It was not a fun night.  No pictures today, too cold to stop.

Beautiful morning but tough hiking weather.  Slipped in the snow all morning.   It warmed up this afternoon, melting most of the snow and turning the trail into a river.  Good group at the Shelter tonight.
Long 12 hour walk today. Perfect weather - sunny and mid seventies. Today’s highlight was Clingmans dome which is the highest point on the AT.
Today was my final day day in the smokies. I am staying at an interesting hostel. I washed my clothes on a washboard for the first time ever. Heading back out early tomorrow morning.

Beautiful day in the 60’s.  My legs felt dead today.  I am probably doing too many miles for this early in the hike.  I ate more today than any other day so far.  I have lost what feels like too much weight so I am glad my appetite is increasing. Today’s view from Max Patch Bald was my favorite so far.  Tomorrow thirteen miles into Hot Springs for resupply for a longer five day stretch.

I am loving NC. Beautiful mountains, friendly people. Hot Springs is hosting a hiking festival this weekend which means lots of hikers in town. Easier thirteen miles today arriving at my room around one o’clock, Costly resupply in town and now waiting on fish fry on the property I am staying at.  I have a long day scheduled tomorrow, so have to be ready to go early in the a.m.

Today was my roughest day on the trail so far.  I don’t think I am sick but felt lethargic the entire day.  A hard steep climb out of Hot Springs took forever and I never regained my strength throughout the day.  It was a great time at the hiker festival last night in Hot Springs. I ran into some people that I hadn’t seen since the first week.

It rained all day today but the temps were in the 50’s so it wasn’t too bad.  Lots of rock scrambles today where you had to collapse your hiking poles and use your hands.  I made a critical mistake today and lost my tent stakes. I took a hard fall and I think that is where I lost them. I used sticks and rocks to set up the tent. Definitely not an ideal situation. One more night before I get to Erwin, TN where I can replace them.  Stacy arrives in Erwin on Thursday.  I can’t wait to see her.

I made it into Erwin yesterday afternoon. I am going to spend two days here with Stacy and then head back out on Saturday. The weather was rough the last couple of days, lots of rain. On Tuesday I was in my tent from 4:30 p.m. till 6:30 a.m.Getting all my chores done, fixing air mattress, buying new tent stakes and cleaning mud off of everything. I am also eating as much as I can. I have lost sixteen pounds already which is way too much for this early in the trip. I am now at mile 343. I will update again on Saturday.

We had a great two days together but it was hard to say goodbye to Stacy this morning.I felt rested and the miles came easily today.  Today’s best view was from the top of a bald called Beauty Spot.  It is easily accessed by car so it was busy with today being Saturday.
Best views of the trip so far from atop Grassy Ridge Bald. Stunning, pictures won’t do it justice. My legs are feeling much better the last two days after the extended break,

I crossed the 400 mile mark today.  I also left North Carolina for the last time. The trail had been crossing back and forth between North Carolina and Tennessee.  Now only a few more days left in Tennessee before entering Virginia.  Perfect weather again today.  I am camped next to a creek tonight.

I am staying at the hostel at Black Bear Resort.  I sent my food supply here for the next three days.  That should get me into Damascus, Virginia on Friday.I will Usually start each day with 16 ounces of coffee while I pack up camp.  After hiking two miles I will start to eat snacks for breakfast.  Normally this would be RX bars, Cashews, Almonds,Snickers and Cliff bars.  Lunch consists of either peanut butter, Hard Salami, tuna or Pepperoni on a flour tortilla or bagel chips.  For dinner, I have been eating Mountain House meals that you add hot water to the pouch they come in or ramen or instant potatoes with tuna packets. Then when I get to town I eat whatever I can.  One evening in Erwin I ate a Double Quarter pounder with cheese, fries and coke along with four soft tacos.
Today was warm, temps in the 80’s.  Walked several miles around Watauga Lake which was beautiful. Two more days and I enter Virginia.

I made it into Damascus, Virginia today for resupply.  I also finished my third state when I crossed into Virginia three miles south of Damascus.  The AT runs through fourteen states but 1/4 of the trail, which is over 500 miles, is located in Virginia. Hikers refer to it as the Virginia blues because you feel as though you are not making any progress.  So I will be spending at least a month in Virginia.

The weather wasn’t nearly as bad as predicted today.  It rained hard for about an hour but not all day as expected.  More rain coming tonight and tomorrow. The trail intersected and joined the Creeper Trail a popular biking path.  Lots of riders out despite the weather. Tomorrow I will cross the 500 mile mark.
Saw the wild ponies today at Grayson Highlands. They approach you and try to lick the salt off the handles of your trekking poles.

The third straight day of rain chased me to the town of Marion.  A gentleman whose son thru-hiked in 2014, drove us the eight miles to town.  He has been shuttling people for three years and estimates he has given 1700 rides.  His van that he recently replaced had 348,000 miles.  So many great people out here.

Shorter twelve mile hike into Atkins to pick up my resupply box.  I have been really low on energy again and need to re-evaluate my diet and daily mileage.  Staying at the Relax Inn.  Sign out front says 'Color TV'.
Today’s highlight was crossing the 550 mile mark which means I have completed 1/4 of the trail. Beautiful sunny day.
Tough 16 miles today. Steep grades on both the uphills and downhills. I am still feeling lethargic. Hoping a shorter day tomorrow will energize me.

I have been hiking with Pacer, a 62 year old hiker from New York.  He is a five day a week CrossFit member in excellent condition. Yesterday I encouraged him to hike ahead as I knew I was holding him back.  He is getting stronger, I am not.  Hopefully We will cross paths again soon. Easy twelve miles into Bland, VA but hitchhiking to the hotel did not go well so that added four bonus miles. For Tomorrow, I have secured a shuttle back to the trail at 7 a.m.from Bubba the area shuttle driver.  I love these rural hotel signs.
Resupply in Pearisburg tomorrow morning before hiking out.  Happy Mother’s Day to all the mothers today and especially to my mom, wife and daughter in law.  Missing them all today.
Late start out of Pearisburg today.I have been on the trail six weeks today, 42 days. 39 days hiking 3 zero days for an average of 15.47 miles per day.

Lots of rain the last two days.  I also happened to be on a very rocky section of trail.  Three falls in two days.  I will try to get a good picture of the slabs and boulders that are the trail. Too wet for my phone so no pictures.
Downpour today.  It was warm enough that I only wore a t-shirt.Hiked up to Dragons Tooth today.  It was the hardest rock scramble so far.  Tomorrow, planning a long day in the rain.

Hi,I have been without a phone for the past week. Stacy is here now with another phone. I will try to keep this one dry.  We are staying with a great young couple Mike and Alex at the Blue Heron cottage.  This has been my favorite place I have stayed so far.  It is located in Tyro, Virginia on the Tye river. The miles have been tough. Back to back three thousand foot climbs the past couple of days. I am going to head out early tomorrow to complete ten miles. Stacy will Meet me when I finish and we are going to head to Waynesboro to resupply.  Sunday I will hike twenty miles to Waynesboro and Stacy will head home.The picture was taken on McAfee knob the most photographed location on the AT.

I finished my ten mile hike today before the rain hit.  It is pouring now with rain forecasted for the next week.  Leaving tomorrow and saying goodbye to Stacy will be tough.  Missing my granddaughter, Madilyn.

The rain held off today until I reached a motel just before the entrance to Shenandoah National Park. Tomorrow, I enter the park.  The trail runs along Skyline Drive which is the main road through the park. It has easy access to food and showers but will be quite crowded, especially on a Holiday weekend.

First day in Shenandoah was tough. The humidity was high which lead to a long day.  I switched out my sleeping bag for a 40 degree quilt that I am using for the first time tonight.  I sent home some  warmer clothes as well.  I will have to get my winter stuff back when I reach New Hampshire.

Sunny skies today after a night of heavy rains.Five people mentioned seeing bears today. I still haven’t seen one after 900 miles. I would like to see one on the trail but not in camp. I am going to stay at the lodge tomorrow. I need a shower bad.

I left early and finished 15 miles before noon. I saw my first bear before daybreak while hiking by headlamp. I also saw several deer that were not concerned with my presence and let me pass just a few feet from them.Terrible weather in the forecast.
Went from lodge to lodge to avoid sleeping in the thunderstorms and flash floods.

Today was a long day. I started in the dark at 5 a.m. I saw three bears in a half mile stretch around eight o’clock. When they saw me, each of them would retreat a few yards into the woods jump On a rock and face me while watching me walk by.   I was able to get one blurry picture.Big storms rolling in again as I type.
Shorter day into Front Royal. I have exited the Shenandoahs. Three days from Now I will finally finish Virginia.

I didn’t hike on Sunday due to the heavy rains and flooding.Today I felt great and the 24 miles flew by.  We had to ford several creeks and rivers that would normally just be an easy rock hop to cross. Tomorrow I will cross the one thousand mile mark.

Today we tackled the roller coaster, thirteen and a half miles of trail that go up and down over twelve mountains.  It didn’t look that tough when looking at the elevation profile, but it was brutal. Around lunch three of us decided to hitch to a town for restraunt food.  Stan, a race horse owner, picked us up in his brand new truck drove us a few miles before we determined we were going the wrong way. He stopped at a gas station where we got food and then was nice enough to drive us back to our pickup spot.  Thanks, Stan!When we returned two younger hikers, Handstand and Pixies parents were at the crossing with food, pop and beer.  It was great to meet and talk to them.We spent the night at Bear Foot Hostel where Hiker Mama welcomes hikers to stay in the walkout basement of her beautiful home.I also crossed the 1000 mile mark today.

Short day today into Harpers Ferry for resupply and a trip to the Appalachian Trail Headquarters. The office is considered the unofficial half way point mark of the trail. There you get your picture taken and your information recorded into a notebook. When I left Springer Mountain Georgia on April 3, I was the 1822 person to start the thru-hike this year. I was the 587th to reach the halfway point. I also left Virginia today after 550 miles. Tomorrow only four miles in West Virginia before entering Maryland.

Long day.  I left my hotel at 4:45 a.m. after a poor nights sleep.  Perfect hiking weather today with a high in the low 70’s.  I walked thirteen miles of trail today in Maryland that were part of the first 50 mile race that I did eight years ago, the JFK 50 mile. The race covered the miles in the southbound direction, today, of course, I was going north.  Finished West Virginia today. Tomorrow I will leave Maryland and enter Pennsylvania.
I crossed the Mason Dixon line and entered Pennsylvania today.
I have been sick for four days and am currently back in Illinois and being treated for Giardia. I started antibiotics today and hope to start feeling better soon.
I have finished my antibiotics and am feeling better. Tomorrow I will drive back to Pennsylvania and on Wednesday I will start walking to Maine.

Fairly easy trail for my first day back. I felt surprisingly good except for my feet which are pretty beat up from the Pennsylvania rocks. The Pennsylvania segment of the AT is famous for being rocky. The rocks get worse and the trail gets more difficult as you get further north.

I crossed the 1100 mile mark today. That is a large chunk of the trail but still so many miles remain. Went through the Boulder maze today. It was pretty crazy. You had to toss your poles ahead of you and use your hands to scramble up in some spots. Shorter day into town tomorrow.

14 flat easy miles into Carlisle today. The trail passed through several farm fields and pastures. I enjoyed the expansive views. My legs are really sore, probably due to hiking too many miles too quickly after the long break.

Lots of rain again today. I am eating at the historic Doyle Hotel in Duncannon, interesting place.  I feel much better today. Hopefully I am getting my trail legs back. Heading out early tomorrow,more rain in the forecast.

There were several rattlesnakes and copperheads spotted in the rocks on the trail today.  I only saw one small snake but everyone that was walking in the opposite direction had a warning about the snakes that they had encountered.Tomorrow 14 miles and resupply.
Today would have been a great day to do big miles.  Beautiful weather with low humidity.  I had to grab a package so I stopped at 14 miles here in Jonestown. Heading out again early in the morning.
I went over 1200 miles today and now have less than 1000 miles remaining. Beautiful day 50’s in the morning, 70’s this afternoon.

Hot temperatures have led to long hiking days.  I have had to take more frequent breaks this week with daytime highs in the 90s. Tomorrow it is supposed to be 99 so I am starting early with hopes of finishing 15 miles by noon. Last day in Pennsylvania tomorrow.

We woke up early and Stacy drove me to the trailhead at 5 a.m.  I was able to finish 15 miles by 11:00.  Temperatures reached 99 today, so it was a good day to get done early.  Same plan for tomorrow as the heatwave continues. Tomorrow I will cross the Delaware River and enter New Jersey. I will also go Over 1300 miles.

Still very hot and humid.  Started early, finished early.  Grateful to be able to sleep indoors the last two nights.  After I finished we took Giant, a nice kid from Tempe AZ to the doctors,  pharmacy and his hotel.  He has been sick for the last few days.  Hopefully he will be back out on the trail in a day or two.
Still really hot out here. I was able to finish 15 miles by 10:30 a.m. Many more views here in New Jersey than in Pennsylvania.  Enjoying the trail here so far.
Crazy rock scrambles in the rain today.  Definitely the sketchiest climbs of the hike.  I made it into New York today.  Stacy heads back to Illinois tomorrow.

The AT in New York has been much tougher hiking than I anticipated.  The change in elevation hasn’t been extreme but the grade of the climbs and descents have been steep.   The trail never levels off here, always up or down.There has been no water in New  York. There are not many sources to begin with and they have all been dry so far.  Thanks to the area people that left several gallons of water at four different road crossings today.  Near the end of the day I had to take a long road walk to a State Park entrance that had a faucet to fill up for the night and morning.

There were lots of weekenders walking up and down Bear Mountain today .  It is a beautiful path that must have taken hundreds of hours to construct all of the stairs that make up the  staircase.  Today I went over 1400 miles.  Tomorrow I cross the Hudson River.

Three tough long days. I walked 22, 25 and 18 miles the last three days.  Made it to Kent, CT today. Eating some real food here and hiking out this evening.  Shorter day tomorrow and a hotel stay and resupply.  Water continues to be the biggest concern.  Most of the sources continue to be dry.

Shorter day today into Cornwall Bridge for resupply. My old legs have been struggling the past few days.  I have two long days ahead, then may have to slow down a bit and take a day or two off.I walked along the Housatonic river for several miles today.  I think the river walks have been my favorite stretches of trail so far.
I love the small towns along the trail in Connecticut.  It is such a beautiful area. I went over 1500 miles today and will enter Massachusetts tomorrow. Only  four states to go.

Climbed Bear Mountain first thing in the morning.  It is the highest peak in Connecticut.  The descent heading north was crazy steep.  Shortly thereafter I entered Massachusetts and the terrain became even tougher.  It was a hard sixteen miles today. Signs of things to come.
I am taking a day off in Beckett MA. There are flash flood warnings and the area is expecting at least two inches of rain.
An easy 19 mile day into Dalton, MA today.  Beautiful day, 75 with low humidity. The trail runs through Dalton for one and a half miles.

I am currently at mile 1593. Tomorrow I will go over 1600 miles and enter Vermont. Massachusetts was beautiful. The views from Mt Greylock were amazing. You can drive to the summit so it was quite busy. Once in Vermont the Appalachian Trail follows the Vermont Long Trail for 105 miles.
Back to back 22 mile days has me camping on Stratton Mountain. Beautiful day yesterday, lots of rain today. Rain is in the forecast for the remainder of the week.

Crazy weather today.  Stormed all night and all day.  I had two sketchy river crossings where if you fell you would be in big trouble.  After walking most of the day in the rain the nice people at The Lodge at Bromley showed up in two minutes and shuttled me to their lodge for a night indoors. It is a ski lodge that looks pretty empty tonight. I have been having issues with my knee for about a week so I may take a half or full day off tomorrow.  View from my balcony.

I have been back home in Illinois for a few days. After resting my knee for a couple days, I hiked out on Thursday only to make it five miles before heading back. The pain is in the the same location where I had a meniscus tear a couple of years ago.   My plan is to finish next year, starting around June 1st. If you followed this journal, thanks. I apologize that the entries were brief.  I overestimated the energy and desire I would have to write at the end of a twenty mile day of hiking.Thanks to Stacy for all your support and encouragement.  I couldn’t have made it this far without you.I am extremely disappointed at not being able to finish this year but I will be back.
